awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: De Rham-Hodge theory modeling and learning of biomolecular data
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the rules of life is the major mission of biological sciences in the 21st Century. The availability of massive biological data and the recent advances in computational algorithms have paved the way for biological sciences to transition from a qualitative, phenomenological and descriptive to a quantitative, analytical and predictive approach. However, this transition is hindered by tremendous structural complexity and excessively large datasets. For example, even all the world's computers put together do not have enough power to design drugs automatically because of the structural complexity of protein-drug interactions, excessively large datasets associated with drug configurations, and the high dimensionality of involved molecular simulation and/or machine learning. These challenges will be addressed by innovative mathematical strategies in the present project. A team from mathematics and computer science at Michigan State University will turn sophisticated mathematics into computational algorithms that create simplified representations of complex biomolecules or their interactions. As a result, deep learning and other types of machine learning can be efficiently carried out to extract the structure-function relationship from massive and diverse biomolecular datasets. This information will be extremely valuable for revealing the rules of life and for design new biomolecules, including biomedicine, which ultimately tests our understanding of the biomolecular world and brings a direct benefit to human health. Additionally, this project will support the development of undergraduate and graduate-level courses on computational biophysics and machine learning at Michigan State University. Finally, this research will facilitate the cross-disciplinary training of the next generation researchers who are experts on advanced mathematics, computer algorithms, and molecular-level biology.

The objective of the present project is to develop novel de Rham-Hodge theory-based approaches to revolutionize the current practice in biomolecular data analysis and modeling. The de Rham-Hodge theory is a hallmark of the 20th Century?s mathematics that has had a great impact in modern mathematics, quantum physics, and computer science. The investigators will introduce for the first time the de Rham-Hodge theory to reduce the structural complexity of biomolecules. Additionally, the research team will propose the persistent de Rham-Hodge theory and element-specific de Rham-Hodge theory for the first time to properly encode chemical and biological information in biomolecular data representation. These methods will be carefully integrated with advanced machine learning or deep learning algorithms to reveal biomolecular structure-function relationships. Moreover, the investigators will extensively validate the proposed methods on a variety of datasets, such as protein binding to the proteins, ligands, DNA and RNA, protein folding stability changes upon mutation, drug toxicity, solvation, solubility, and partition coefficient. Finally, user-friendly software packages and online servers will be developed using parallel and GPU architectures for researchers who are not formally trained in advanced mathematics or sophisticated machine learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project began in August 2019 and lasted for five years, overlapping with the COVID-19 pandemic. It provided a real-world test for our theoretical machine learning developments. In May 2020, we predicted two residue sites, 452 and 501, on the SARS-CoV-2 spike as key mutation sites for viral evolution (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmb.2020.07.009). These sites were later confirmed to host the key mutations of all prevailing variants, including Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, Theta, Mu, Omicron (BA.2, BA.4, and BA.5), and others.

In summer 2020, we discovered the SARS-CoV-2 evolution mechanism of natural selection via mutation-induced infectivity strengthening (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmb.2020.07.009). To the best of our knowledge, our team was the first to report this mechanism, utilizing a spike-ACE2 model, AI predictions of binding affinity changes upon mutation, and viral genome genotyping.

In late 2021, we identified another SARS-CoV-2 evolution mechanism: natural selection via antibody resistance (or vaccine breakthrough) (https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpclett.1c03380). Our team was the first to report this mechanism using AI-predicted mutational disruptions of 135 antibody-spike binding complexes and correlating virus mutations with vaccination rates across countries.

Leveraging these two mechanisms, we successfully forecasted the emerging dominance of Omicron BA.2 in early February 2022 (https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.05031), which the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed in late March 2022. Similarly, we forecasted the dominance of Omicron BA.4 and BA.5 on May 1, 2022 (https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.00532.pdf), confirmed by the WHO in early July 2022.

On December 1, 2021, just five days after the WHO’s announcement of the Omicron (B.1.1.529) variant on November 26, we predicted its disruption of FDA-approved monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) from Eli Lilly and several mAbs from Celltrion and Rockefeller University (https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.01318). These predictions were later validated experimentally, as the necessary data was unavailable at the time of our forecasts.

We have developed a new mathematical paradigm, persistent topological Laplacians (PTLs), which extends topological data analysis from traditional persistent homology to persistent spectral theory (https://doi.org/10.1002/cnm.3376, Doi: 10.3934/dcdsb.2020257). Since its inception in 2019, this framework has been implemented across various topological spaces, including simplicial complexes, path complexes, cellular sheaves, directed flag complexes, and directed hypergraphs. Our PTLs further generalize topological deep learning (TDL), a concept we first introduced (Cang and Wei) in 2017. While TDL is now an emerging paradigm in artificial intelligence (AI) and data science, PTL is a trending topic in topological data analysis.

Knot theory, a foundational branch of mathematics, has been a research focus for over 200 years. Despite its extensive applications, it has traditionally been limited to qualitative analysis. We introduced a multiscale knot theory paradigm that transitions from qualitative to quantitative analysis, offering a powerful computational biology tool. For instance, drug discovery, a challenging scientific endeavor, benefits from this paradigm through advancements in protein-ligand binding affinity scoring. Additional applications include quantitative protein flexibility analysis, drug toxicity evaluation, and drug side-effect screening. This paradigm also paves the way for new explorations in mathematical science, data science, and AI.

Over the past five years, we have published approximately 100 journal papers, including many in prestigious journals such as Nature Machine Intelligence, Nature Computational Science, Nature Communications, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and Chemical Reviews.


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: Guowei Wei
